definitions.definition: the act of firing a gun; the sound this makes

examples.text: We **heard** some **shots** in the distance.
Someone **took a shot at** the car.
She was killed by a single shot to the head.
The man **fired** several **shots** from his pistol.
I heard a pistol shot.
The shot hit him in the chest.

definitions.definition: a person who shoots a gun in a particular way (well, badly, etc.)

examples.text: She is a crack shot with a rifle.

definitions.definition: an attempt to score a goal or point in a game

examples.text: He **took a shot** from the edge of the box.
Taylor scored with a low shot into the corner of the net.
She turned and **hit a shot** that looked like a certain goal.
A defender managed to **block** his **shot**.
Unfortunately her shot at goal missed.
England had a few shots on goal.
He scuffed a shot from the edge of the box.
I took a few more shots at the target, but missed every time.
My first shot went wide, but my second was right on target.
The goalkeeper parried his first shot but he scored from the rebound.
Their captain tried a long shot on goal.
her right-footed shot from outside the penalty area

definitions.definition: an act of hitting the ball

examples.text: Good shot!
Go on—take another shot.
She started the day one shot off the lead.

definitions.definition: the heavy ball that is used in the sports competition called shot-put
a photograph

examples.text: We stood there patiently while he snapped a few shots.
I **got** some good **shots** of people at the party.
I decided to stop and **take** a quick **shot** of the street.
I tried to get a shot of him in the water.
publicity shots
She took a wide-angle shot of the house and garden.
Kate snapped a few shots with her camera through the window.
I got some great shots of the runners as they crossed the line.

definitions.definition: a scene in a film that is filmed continuously by one camera

examples.text: the opening shot of a character walking across a desert
The director is clearly fond of tracking and aerial shots.
The exterior shots were filmed in Morocco and Malta.

definitions.definition: a large number of small metal balls that you fire together from a shotgun

examples.text: Round shot whistled over our heads.
Conservationists have called on the government to ban the use of lead shot in shotgun cartridges.

definitions.definition: a large stone or metal ball that was shot from a cannon or large gun in the past
a remark or an action that is usually one of a series, and is aimed against somebody/something that you are arguing or competing with

examples.text: This statement was **the opening shot** in the argument.
The supermarket **fired the first shot** in a price war today.
He couldn't resist **taking a cheap shot at** his political opponent.
As her parting shot she warned Pete never to come near her again.
the opening shot in the election campaign

definitions.definition: the act of trying to do or achieve something

examples.text: The team are looking good for a shot at the title.
I've never produced a play before but I'll **have a shot at** it.
I'm willing to **give it a shot**.
Just **give it your best shot** *(= try as hard as you can)* and you'll be fine.

definitions.definition: a small amount of a drug that is put into your body using a syringe

examples.text: a flu shot *(= to protect you against flu)*
a shot of morphine
Have you had all your shots for your expedition yet?
The applause acted on her like a shot of adrenalin.
a shot of penicillin

definitions.definition: a small amount of a drink, especially a strong alcoholic one

examples.text: a shot of whisky

definitions.definition: the process of sending a spacecraft into and through space

examples.text: The **space shot** was shown live on television.
a moon shot

definitions.definition: a horse, dog, etc. that has the particular chance of winning a race that is mentioned

examples.text: The horse is a 10–1 shot.

definitions.definition: an important person
to be the person who controls a situation
very quickly and without hesitating

examples.text: If I had the chance to go there, I'd go like a shot.

definitions.definition: an attempt or a guess that is not likely to be successful but is worth trying

examples.text: It's a long shot, but it just might work.

definitions.definition: not nearly; not at all

examples.text: It's not over yet—not by a long shot.

definitions.definition: a final remark, especially an unkind one, that somebody makes as they leave

examples.text: As her parting shot she warned Pete never to come near her again.

definitions.definition: something that you say or do as a warning to somebody about what might happen if they do not change, etc.
something that encourages somebody/something or gives them the help they need

examples.text: Their enthusiasm has been a shot in the arm for all of us.

definitions.definition: a guess; something you do without knowing what the result will be

examples.text: The figure he came up with was really just a shot in the dark.
It was only a stab in the dark, but I hoped I might be right.

wordOrigin: noun Old English sc(e)ot, gesc(e)ot of Germanic origin; related to German Geschoss, from the base of the verb shoot.
